comments:
Build 20040420

When restarting Eclipse with Cheetah03 update, the log gets filled with stack 
traces (see below).

Steps:
1- install build 20040420
2- start it on fresh workspace, at welcome just go to workbench
3- go to update manager, and install Cheetah03 using instructions posted at:
    http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/jdt-core-
home/r3.0/main.html#updates
4- restart when prompted
5- switch to Java perspective --> endless dumping in log

Jeff, I ran this with trace on (the .options from update.configurator) and 
notice that update is installing the new plugin and uninstalling the old one.
Do you have any thoughts on what could go wrong?

This looks like a dup of bug 57995

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 57995 ***

Just to clarify. I believe it is along the same line as bug 57995; but it is 
now getting worse. 

You can no longer switch to Java perspective, no matter how many times you 
restart Eclipse. In 57995, there seemed to be an issue with initial restart, or 
if the Java perspective had no been open before installing the patch.

Now, whether or not the Java perspective got opened prior to patching, does not 
make a difference. No matter how many times you restart.

Cheetah cannot be installed on this build, period.

Raising severity, as unless this is fixed promptly, we cannot deliver further 
Cheetah updates. There are API changes in latest JDT Core, now reflected in 
Cheetah as well, and in order for new Cheetah updates to be functional, it 
needs to be able to install on latest I-builds.

Alternatively, I could quit using update completely, and simply issue jdt.core 
updates with Cheetah (as we did expose our previews) from now on.

We need someone from runtime to take a look at this too. When I run eclipse 
with -console and type the ss command to see what bundle states there are, 
everything appears fine.

Philippe and I have been looking at it this morning.  Here is some summary

The original stack trace does not show that the cause of the 
NoClassDefFoundError is in fact an NPE as shown below.

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.search.indexing.IndexManager.getJavaPluginWorkingL
ocation(IndexManager.java:230)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.search.indexing.IndexManager.<init>
(IndexManager.java:45)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelManager.<init>
(JavaModelManager.java:485)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelManager.<clinit>
(JavaModelManager.java:463)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.core.JavaCore.create(JavaCore.java:1101)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaElementContainmentAdapter.<init>
(JavaElementContainmentAdapter.java:26)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaElementAdapterFactory.<clinit>
(JavaElementAdapterFactory.java:62)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaPlugin.registerAdapters
(JavaPlugin.java:701)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaPlugin.startup(JavaPlugin.java:317)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.compatibility.PluginActivator.start
(PluginActivator.java:49)

This NPE is in code that does
    return this.javaPluginLocation = JavaCore.getPlugin().getStateLocation();
JavaCore.getPlugin is returning null

On looking at my osgi console I noticed

90	     	ACTIVE     
reference:file:/d:/test/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0/ [90]
93	     	ACTIVE     
reference:file:/d:/test/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0.cheetah03/ 
[93]

There are two jdt.core plugins installed and ACTIVE.  This has got to be a bad 
thing.  There really ought not be any case in which this should happen as the 
plugin is (should be) a singleton.

so, it is ok for the two to be installed but only one should be active.

We think we know what the problem is.  When cheetah is applied it is a PATCH.  
As such, update uninstalls the old jdt.core and installs the new jdt.core.  
They then call refreshPackages() with a list containing just the cheetah 
jdt.core.  The OSGi design point here is that really this should be an *update* 
not an uninstall/install.  As such, there is no way of calling refreshPackages 
with both the old and the new bundles.

The "real" fix is for Update to use update().  However, this brings in alot of 
other issues we have been hoping to avoid and certainly cannot manage at this 
point in the cycle.  

So, Tom is going ot look at changing the way refreshPackages() works to have it 
always include the set of "removalPending" bundles (i.e., the old jdt.core in 
this case).  This will still be within the OSGi spec but will hinder some 
peripheral usecases (uninstalling and installing disjoint groups of bundles and 
refreshing independently).

The net is that we should have a patch to try later today.

Moving this to Equinox and assigning to Tom.

Created an attachment (id=9884)
Fixed org.eclispse.osgi project for I20040422 build

A fix has been checked into head.  I have attached a built version of
org.eclipse.osgi.  This was built from the code in HEAD except the
eclipse.properties file includes the org.eclipse.osgi.util in the base bundles
to install.

This should allow you to extract the new version of osgi onto the I20040422
build.
A has been checked into head.

I just grabbed the patch and tried it over clean I20040422. I successfully 
installed Cheetah03 in it with no exceptions in log during restart.
However in the end Cheetah is not enabled (check compiler preference page, you 
should see a 1.5 tab).

I have the impression that your fix did resolve the duplicate, but picked the 
wrong one.

Actually, after subsequent restart, the 1.t tab is now present, indicating the 
Cheetah got enabled in the end. It seems that the initial restart is busted 
somehow.

To reproduce the offending behavior:
1. expand I20040420
2. start it on empty workspace
3. jump to update manager and install Cheetah03
4. restart when prompted
5. go to compiler preference page, observe the 1.5 tab is MISSING!
6. exit/restart again
7. go to compiler preference page, observe the 1.5 tab is PRESENT !

Just to clarify, the pref page is revealed only if a new preference is detected 
from the Cheetah contribution. So it is a good indicator of the problem.

One interesting point though is that after initial restart, if you look for 
plug-in details (about dialog), there is no trace of JDT plugins as if 
something was wrong there...

Also, during initial restart, log shows:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi Apr 23, 2004 00:30:04.224
!MESSAGE Bundle 
reference:file:/d:/cheetah/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0.cheetah03/
 [86] was not resolved.

Reproduced in OSGi console mode:
osgi> diag 86
reference:file:/d:/cheetah/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0.cheetah03/
 [86]
  No unresolved constraints.

Tom and I spent some time looking this evening and with the patch, everything 
works find for both of us.  I tried in both 0422 and 0420.  Please confirm the 
steps:
- fresh install, fresh workspace
- run, skip intro
- use update manager to fetch and install Cheetah03 patch
- restart when prompted
- on restart, go to Window->Preferences->Java->Compiler and look for the 1.5 
tab.

This tab is there for us.  

Tom did feel he saw the problem earlier in the day but wsa not able to 
reproduce.  There may be an element of timing.

One bizarre thought...  Way back when we used to have resources tests that 
failed because the disk was not actually being updated fast enough.  If we ran 
two tests too close together they would interfere.  Could it be that we are 
restarting and seeing old data?

Philippe could you
- confirm the above steps
- see if you can reproduce on 0422 with the patch
- if you cannot, pop a bottle of wine...
- if you can, try again but instead of restarting, say no and immediately exit, 
wait a few seconds and then manually restart.

There is very little room we can see for race conditions in the code.  There 
are multiple threads but Main is waiting on the start level thread which does 
the uninstall/install/refresh (and waits for the refresh thread to finish).  
During this time, nothing else should be happening as we are VERY early in the 
startup sequence and no other bundles (other than runtime) have been kicked.

Steps look good.
Yesterday attempts with the fix where on a T21 laptop (somewhat slow). I tried 
with a P4 2.4GHz workstation, and reproduced it as well.

restarting, the problem still occurs upon next restart.

No matter how long I wait in between manual exit and manual restart, the 
problem still shows up on both my machines.

timing doesn't seem to be in this area, if any.

It takes me a while sometimes to reproduce this defect, but I finally got it to 
reproduce and I have some platform.xml files that may help you.  Here is what I 
did:

resolved

Thanks Tom.
I bet that the .log file has some message "Could not rename temp file".
This is one of the bugs I've seen a couple of times and could not track it 
down.

When the new platform.xml is saved the algorithm is:

- move current platform.xml to the history directory
- save the configuration into platform.xml.tmp
- change the timestamp of platform.xml.tmp to be that of what we wrote in the 
file
- rename platform.xml.tmp to platform.xml

somehow, the last step fails and this can cause problems.

Note that saving of xml data is done using the JDK classes for XML 
serialization (Transformer).
We have "finally" clauses around all i/o code that should close all the 
streams, but it looks like something may get locked and platform.xml is not 
saved.

I appears there is some conflicting views of the file system between java and 
the os.
Actually, it is the first step that fails (backing up current configuration).

moving bug to update for investigating the i/o failures.
I assume the osgi patch has been submitted as well.
The original failure was caused by not having this osgi fix, and the latest 
problem is caused by update not saving the platform.xml.
Philippe, can you still reproduce the problem with today's nightly build?

I have not been able to reproduce this bug and I also added some code for 
synchronizing the file system cache  with the hard disk, to avoid any 
discrepancies.
I am closing the bug, but if anybody can reproduce it with a clean 0505 
integration build, please re-open.

I can't help with the update logs but the OSGi related logs entries look 
interesting.  In particular, there are a series which look like

!MESSAGE Bundle 
update@/d:/cheetah/sdk/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0.cheetah04/ 
[89] was not resolved.
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.osgi May 05, 2004 23:47:18.359
!MESSAGE Bundle 
update@/d:/cheetah/sdk/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0.cheetah04/ 
was picked instead.

The interesting thing here is that the two plugins listed are the same!  It is 
saying that cheetah04 is not resolved because cheetah04 was picked instead.

This either indicates that...
- the error message is wrong (unlikely)
- the cheetah plugin is somehow in there twice and it is two instances of the 
same plugin that are fighting
- there is a bug in the resolver

I still can't help believe that it is related to the disk file issues that 
Dorian was talking about.  I have not retried in the last few days but I was 
completely unable to reproduce this and Tom only had it in a particular case.

I'll bang more on this on a Win2K machine tomorrow, as apparently, another bug 
that may have to do with file system caching/locking could be reproduced here 
by Konrad.

Using 20040511, it is getting worse. I cannot even open the update manager.

If I discard my existing workspace, and start clean again, then the update 
process works fine, and cheetah is enabled on first restart as expected.

Thanks Philippe!

So, the original bug appears to be fixed.
I will look at the new problem (comment #46), but it looks like there is 
something outside the update domain. I've opened bug 61923 to track this 
problem.
There have been ClassCastException bugs in the UI recentely, so perhaps this 
one falls under the same umbrela.
